data.title: Photoshop CC For Dummies Cheat Sheet
data.meta_description: Keep this Cheat Sheet handy when you're working Photoshop for quick reference to selection tricks, troubleshooting, and more.
data.text:
When you run into a problem with Photoshop CC, like the program wonât do what you want it to, or Photoshop simply wonât do anything, try these quick fixes to troubleshoot:

When Photoshop tools donât work

Deselect. Unless youâre trying to work within an active selection, press Command+D (Mac) or Ctrl+D (Windows) to deselect. An active selection elsewhere may be restricting your work.

Reset the tool. Right-click on the tool icon at the left end of the Options bar and select choose Reset Tool from the drop-down menu.

Check the Layers and Channels panels. Make sure you have the correct layer active and that the layer (not a layer mask) is active. Check the Channels panel to make sure you have the color channels active.

When Photoshop commands arenât available

You move the cursor to the menu and click, only to discover that the command you want is grayed out! Your next stop should be the ImageâMode menu. Check to make sure that the imageâs color mode and color depth are appropriate for the command you want to use. (Many of Photoshopâs filters, for example, can be used only with 8-bit/RGB images.)

Fixing Photoshop

When Photoshop just wonât work properly, try replacing the Preferences file by using this procedure:

Open Photoshop and save your custom goodies. Choose EditâPresetsâPreset Manager to save sets of styles, brushes, and other such bits and pieces you created. Use the Save Actions command in the Actions panel menu to save any sets of custom Actions.

Review your Preferences. Open Photoshopâs Preferences and go through each pane, noting your preferred settings so that you can restore your work environment later.

Quit Photoshop. You then restart the program like this:

On a Mac: Hold down Command+Shift+Option and restart Photoshop. When prompted, release the modifier keys and confirm, that yes, you do want to replace the Photoshop settings.

On a PC: Restart Photoshop and then immediately press and hold down Ctrl+Shift+Alt. When prompted, release the modifier keys and confirm, that yes, you do want to replace the Photoshop settings.

Many of Photoshop CCâs creative filters use foreground color, background color, or both, and you should select these colors before you get into the Filter gallery. Use this list for important Photoshop filters and the colors they use:

Filter Color(s) Filter Color(s) ArtisticâColored Pencil Background SketchâGraphic Pen Foreground + background ArtisticâNeon Glow Foreground + background SketchâHalftone Pattern Foreground + background Brush StrokesâAccented Edges Foreground + background SketchâNote Paper Foreground + background DistortâDiffuse Glow Background SketchâPhotocopy Foreground + background SketchâPlaster Foreground + background SketchâReticulation Foreground + background SketchâBas Relief Foreground + background SketchâStamp Foreground + background SketchâChalk & Charcoal Foreground + background SketchâTorn Edges Foreground + background SketchâConte Crayon Foreground + background TextureâStained Glass Foreground

Two filters that are not in the Filter Gallery use Foreground and Background colors. They are: FilterâRenderâClouds; and FilterâRenderâFibers.
